questions.text: Which of the following factors does NOT affect the rate of diffusion in the lung according to Fick's Law? Thickness of the alveolar-capillary membrane Diameter of the bronchiole Surface area of the alveolar-capillary membrane Partial pressure gradient of the gases Temperature Solubility of the Gas
questions.explanation:
Surface Area of the Membrane
  • The greater the surface area available for diffusion, the higher the rate of gas exchange.
  • In diseases like emphysema, where alveolar surface area is reduced, diffusion capacity decreases.

Concentration Gradient
  • A steeper gradient (difference in partial pressures between the alveoli and the blood) increases the diffusion rate.
  • For example, if the alveolar partial pressure of oxygen is high compared to the blood, oxygen will diffuse more rapidly.

Thickness of the Membrane
  • The thinner the membrane (alveolar-capillary membrane), the faster the diffusion rate.
  • Conditions like pulmonary fibrosis increase membrane thickness and reduce diffusion capacity.

Diffusion Coefficient of the Gas
  • Different gases diffuse at different rates.
  • For example, CO2 diffuses more readily than O2 due to its higher diffusion coefficient.

Temperature and Pressure

Higher temperatures increase the diffusion rate, and barometric pressure changes can also influence diffusion rates.

Solubility of the Gas

Gases more soluble in blood (like CO2) will diffuse more readily than gases with lower solubility (like O2).

questions.text: Which of the following parameters belong to static lung volumes and capacities? Maximum Voluntary Ventilation Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) Dead space Residual Volume (RV) Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second (FEV1)
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Static Lung Volumes & Capacities

Dynamic Lung Volumes & Capacities

Measurement Focus

Lung volume without the recording of time

Lung volume to time

Units of Measurement

Measured in millilitres (ml) or litres

Measured in millilitres per second (ml/second)

Examples

Volume:

  • Tidal Volume (TV)
  • Inspiratory Reserve Volume (IRV)
  • Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV)
  • Residual Volume (RV)
  • Anatomical Dead Space
 

Capacity:

  • Total Lung Capacity (TLC)
  • Vital Capacity (VC)
  • Inspiratory Capacity (IC)
  • Functional Residual Capacity (FRC)
  • Forced Vital Capacity (FVC)
  • Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second (FEV1)
  • FEV1/FVC Ratio
  • Peak Expiratory Flow Rate (PEFR)
  • Inspiratory Flow Rate
  • Expiratory Flow Rate

Clinical Significance
  • Assess the maximum air volume the lungs can hold and the different capacities during various breathing phases.
  • Diagnosis of restrictive lung diseases such as fibrosis and sarcoidosis
  • Assess the rate of airflow and lung function over time.
  • Diagnosis of obstructive lung diseases such as asthma and COPD

questions.text: Which of the following parameters cannot be measured by spirometry?
questions.explanation:
Parameter

Method for Measurement

Residual Volume (RV)
  • Body Plethysmography (Best).
  • Gas Dilution (Helium dilution Method).
  • Nitrogen Washout

Functional Residual Capacity (FRC)

Total Lung Capacity (TLC)
  • Body Plethysmography.
  • Gas Dilution (Helium Dilution Method)

Alveolar Dead Space
  • Single-Breath Tests.
  • Imaging Studies.

Diffusing Capacity (DLCO)
  • DLCO Test (Carbon Monoxide Diffusion Test)

questions.text: Which of the following formulas correctly represents the Vital Capacity (VC) of the lungs?
questions.explanation:
Lung Volume/Capacity

Description

Typical Volume (mL)

Formula

Tidal Volume (TV)

Amount of air inhaled or exhaled during normal breath

500

-

Inspiratory Reserve Volume (IRV)

Additional air that can be inhaled after a normal inhalation

3000

-

Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV)

Additional air that can be exhaled after a normal exhalation

1200

-

Residual Volume (RV)

Air remaining in the lungs after a maximal exhalation

1200

-

Anatomical Dead Space

Volume of air in conducting airways where no gas exchange occurs

150

-

Total Lung Capacity (TLC)

Maximum amount of air the lungs can hold

6000

TLC = TV + IRV + ERV + RV

Vital Capacity (VC)

Maximum air exhaled after a maximal inhalation

4800

VC = TV + IRV + ERV

Inspiratory Capacity (IC)

Maximum air inhaled after a normal exhalation

3500

IC = TV + IRV

Functional Residual Capacity (FRC)

Air remaining in the lungs after a normal exhalation

2400

FRC = ERV + RV

questions.text: What is the true statement regarding Closing Volume (CV)?

options.label: A
options.text: CV is the lung volume at which large airways begin to close during inspiration.

options.label: B
options.text: CV measurement is typically performed using a Multi-Breath Helium Dilution Test.

options.label: C
options.text: Increased CV is seen in conditions such as ageing, obstructive lung diseases, obesity, and smoking.

options.label: D
options.text: A normal CV indicates small airway dysfunction and abnormal lung mechanics.

questions.correct_answer: C. Increased CV is seen in conditions such as ageing, obstructive lung diseases, obesity, and smoking.

questions.text: Which of the following is false on the findings of restrictive lung disease?

options.label: C
options.text: Preservation of Forced Expiratory Flow Rates

questions.explanation:
Definition

Lung disorders are characterised by a reduced distensibility of the lungs, compromising lung expansion, and, in turn, reduced lung volumes

Features
  1. Decreased TLC (Total Lung Capacity)
  2. Decreased VC (Vital Capacity)
  3. Decreased RV (Residual Volume)
  4. Preservation of Forced Expiratory Flow Rates.

Pathology

1. Intrinsic Conditions:

  • Destruction of Distal Lung Parenchyma
  • Inflammatory Changes in the Alveolar Interstitium
  • Interstitial Lung Diseases
  • Alterations from Within the Alveolus(oedema or haemorrhage)
 

2. Extrinsic Conditions:

  • Limitations in Neuromuscular Function
  • Chest Wall Movement Impairments

(pleural disorders, obesity, costosternal or costovertebral fusion, thoracic vertebral fusion or deviation)

Parenchymal Restrictive Dysfunction
  • Pulmonary fibrosis
  • Pneumoconiosis
  • Radiation-induced interstitial lung disease

Extra-parenchymal Restrictive Dysfunction

1. Neuromuscular Diseases:

  • Myasthenia gravis
  • Paralysis of diaphragm
  • Muscular dystrophy
 

2. Chest Wall Diseases

  • Kyphoscoliosis
  • Obesity
  • Ankylosing spondylitis

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Peak Expiratory Flow Rate (PEFR)?

options.label: A
options.text: Maximum velocity of flow in litres per minute with air being forced out of the lungs

options.label: B
options.text: Recorded by using the peak-flow meter

options.label: C
options.text: The normal value is 400 to 600 L/min

questions.text: Which of the following is the most sensitive indicator of small airway diseases?
Which of the following is not a component of the respiratory unit?

options.label: A
options.text: Increasing the viscosity of the alveolar fluid, thereby reducing the tendency to collapse

options.label: B
options.text: Interfering with the diffusion of water molecules across the alveolar lining.

options.label: C
options.text: Spreading phospholipids and proteins uniformly across the alveolar surface.

options.label: D
options.text: Forming a film that alters the behavior of water molecules at the air-liquid interface

questions.correct_answer: D. Forming a film that alters the behavior of water molecules at the air-liquid interface

questions.text: Carbon dioxide (CO 2 ) diffuses more rapidly than oxygen (O 2 ) primarily due to which of the following properties?

options.label: D
options.text: Higher partial pressure in the alveoli

questions.text: Which of the following describes Henry's law?

options.label: A
options.text: The volume of a gas is inversely proportional to its pressure at constant temperature.

options.label: B
options.text: A gas's effusion rate is inversely proportional to the square root of its molar mass.

options.label: C
options.text: The solubility of a gas in a liquid is directly proportional to the partial pressure of the gas above the liquid at a constant temperature.

options.label: D
options.text: The volume of a gas is directly proportional to its temperature at constant pressure

questions.correct_answer: C. The solubility of a gas in a liquid is directly proportional to the partial pressure of the gas above the liquid at a constant temperature.
questions.explanation:
Gas

Solubility Coefficient

Oxygen

0.024

Carbon Dioxide

0.57

Carbon Monoxide

0.018

Nitrogen

0.012

Helium

0.008

questions.text: What is the major mode of transport for oxygen in the blood?

options.label: B
options.text: Bound to haemoglobin in red blood cells

questions.correct_answer: B. Bound to haemoglobin in red blood cells

questions.text: Which of the following formulas gives the oxygen extraction ratio (OER) of a substance?
questions.explanation:
Factor

Key Influences

Impact on OER

Oxygen Delivery (DO2)

Cardiac output, Hemoglobin, SpO₂

Decrease leads to increased OER

Oxygen Consumption (VO2)

Metabolic demands (exercise, sepsis)

Increase without DO₂ increase elevates OER

Blood Flow

Vascular diseases, Shock states

Altered blood flow dynamics affect OER

Physiological Conditions

Hypoxia, Anemia, Hypercapnia

Hypoxia increases OER

Dialysis

Hemodynamic changes during dialysis

Higher OER linked to intradialytic hypotension

Age and Health Status

Age-related cardiovascular/respiratory changes

Reduced cardiac output and hemoglobin levels impact OER

Medications/
Treatments

Vasodilators, Inotropes, Mechanical ventilation

Influence blood flow and oxygen delivery, affecting OER

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the oxygen-hemoglobin (O 2 -Hb) dissociation curve except?

options.label: B
options.text: The plateau phase ranges from 10-60 mm Hg.

options.label: C
options.text: The steep phase ensures efficient oxygen delivery to tissues even with small drops in PO 2 .

options.label: D
options.text: P 50 assesses the binding affinity of haemoglobin for oxygen.

questions.correct_answer: B. The plateau phase ranges from 10-60 mm Hg.
questions.explanation:
Steep phase

Plateau phase

Range

10-60 mm Hg

60-100 mm Hg

Characteristics
  • A rapid increase in Hb saturation.
  • Hb ~90% saturated at PO2 of 60 mm Hg.
  • Curve flattens.
  • Small increase in Hb saturation despite PO2 rise.

Significance
  • The steep phase (10-60 mm Hg PO₂) ensures efficient oxygen unloading, where small PO₂ drops cause significant O₂ release, crucial for active muscles and hypoxic conditions (Option C ruled out)
  • It provides a safety buffer.
  • It maintains high Hb saturation (~90%) despite moderate PO2 decreases.
  • It ensures stable oxygen delivery under varying conditions.

questions.text: Which of the following solutions is considered best for blood storage?
In which form is carbon dioxide predominantly transported in the blood?
What is the significance of the Haldane effect?

options.label: A
options.text: Oxygenation promotes CO₂ release in the lungs.

options.label: B
options.text: Deoxygenation enhances oxygen uptake in tissues.

options.label: C
options.text: CO₂ binding boosts oxygen release in tissues.

options.label: D
options.text: Haemoglobin buffers blood pH by binding hydrogen ions.

questions.correct_answer: A. Oxygenation promotes CO₂ release in the lungs.
questions.explanation:
Concept

The binding of oxygen (O2) to haemoglobin in the lungs promotes the release of carbon dioxide (CO2) from the blood.

Mechanism
  • When O2 binds to haemoglobin, it becomes a stronger acid.
  • Increased acidity reduces haemoglobin's tendency to bind CO2 (carbaminohemoglobin), releasing CO2 into the blood.
  • Increased acidity causes haemoglobin to release hydrogen ions (H+), which combine with bicarbonate ions (HCO3-) to form carbonic acid (H2CO3).
  • Carbonic acid dissociates into water and CO2, exhaling into the alveoli.

Effects
  • In the lungs, high partial pressure of oxygen (PO2) shifts the CO2 dissociation curve, causing more CO2 to be released from the blood.
  • This effect approximately doubled the amount of CO2 released in the lungs and picked up in the tissues compared to without this shift.
  • The CO2 dissociation curve shows the effect quantitatively.

Significance

The Haldane Effect is more quantitatively significant in promoting CO2 transport compared to the Bohr effect's role in promoting O2 transport.

questions.text: A biopsy from a segment of the respiratory tree reveals pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells. From which part of the respiratory tract was this sample most likely taken?
Which of the following controls the depth of breathing?
Ondine's curse, or Ondine's syndrome, is a rare disorder of the respiratory control centre. Which of the following is true about Ondine's curse?

options.label: A
options.text: Loss of voluntary, but intact automatic control

options.label: B
options.text: Loss of automatic, but intact voluntary control

options.label: C
options.text: Loss of both automatic and voluntary control

questions.correct_answer: B. Loss of automatic, but intact voluntary control

questions.text: What is the structure responsible for the voluntary control of respiration?
The apneustic centre is inhibited by?
Decreased arterial blood pressure leads to?
questions.explanation:
Peripheral Chemoreceptors

Central Chemoreceptors

Pathway

Decreased arterial pressure → decreased perfusion of peripheral tissues, including the carotid and aortic bodies → hypoxia (decreased oxygen levels) → stimulation of peripheral chemoreceptors.

Decreased arterial pressure → reduced removal of carbon dioxide (CO2) → CO2 retention → increased arterial PCO2 → increased concentration of hydrogen ions (H+) in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) due to the conversion of CO2 to HCO3- and H+ → stimulation of central chemoreceptors in the medulla.

Result

The peripheral chemoreceptors send signals to the respiratory centres in the brainstem to increase the rate and depth of breathing to improve oxygen delivery and restore homeostasis.

The central chemoreceptors also stimulate the respiratory centres to enhance ventilation, thereby increasing the elimination of CO2 and improving blood gas levels.

questions.text: How does the SCUBA demand system ensure that air is supplied to the diver only when needed?

options.label: A
options.text: The air is continuously supplied to the mask at a constant pressure.

options.label: B
options.text: The first-stage reducing valve maintains a constant high pressure on the mask.

options.label: C
options.text: Air is supplied to the mask only during inhalation through a demand valve.

options.label: D
options.text: Exhaled air is redirected back into the tank for reuse.

questions.correct_answer: C. Air is supplied to the mask only during inhalation through a demand valve.
questions.explanation:
Self-contained underwater breathing apparatus (SCUBA)

Aspect

Details

Components

1. Tanks of compressed air or breathing mixture of oxygen and helium

2. First-stage reducing valve (lowers high tank pressure to low pressure)

3. Combination inhalation demand valve and exhalation valve

4. Mask and tube system with small “dead space”

Principle
  • The reducing valve lowers tank pressure to a few mm Hg above surrounding water pressure.
  • Air is delivered to the mask only during inhalation through the demand valve.
  • Exhaled air is expelled into the water, not back into the tank.

Uses
  • Popular in sports and commercial diving (99% of cases).
  • Limited time underwater, e.g., a few minutes at 200 feet depth due to the high airflow needed to remove CO2.

Image

questions.text: What primary physiological change sustains increased ventilation over several days of high-altitude exposure?

options.label: A
options.text: Initial rapid increase in breathing rate.

options.label: D
options.text: Decrease in respiratory rate over time.

questions.correct_answer: B. Compensatory renal excretion of bicarbonate.

questions.text: Which adaptation is associated with long-term high-altitude exposure and helps to enhance oxygen delivery?

options.label: A
options.text: Elevated systemic blood pressure and reduced capillary surface area

options.label: B
options.text: Increased production of erythropoietin and enhanced hemoglobin levels

options.label: C
options.text: Decreased number of red blood cells and lower 2,3-DPG concentration

options.label: D
options.text: Increased pulmonary blood flow and increased oxygen affinity of hemoglobin

questions.correct_answer: B. Increased production of erythropoietin and enhanced hemoglobin levels
questions.explanation:
Changes to Hypoxia

Cardiovascular
  • Pulmonary vasoconstriction
  • Systemic vasodilation
  • Increased Heart Rate, Cardiac Output, Blood Pressure
  • Angiogenesis

RBC
  • Increased Production (EPO, RBC)
  • Increased Hematocrit and Hemoglobin
  • Increased 2,3 - DPG
 

Note: Significant Polycythemia→ increased blood viscosity→ increased workload of heart→ cardiac hypertrophy.

questions.text: Where is the pneumotaxic centre, which regulates respiratory rate, located in the brain?
All of the following statements about Clara cells of the respiratory tract are true except:

options.label: A
options.text: They are found in the bronchioles.

questions.text: A premature infant presents with severe respiratory distress shortly after birth. The neonate is diagnosed with neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS). Which type of alveolar cell is most likely deficient in this condition, leading to inadequate surfactant production?
In the Nitrogen Washout Method for measuring lung volumes, what does the phase III observed in the graph represent?

options.label: A
options.text: The volume of air in the conducting zone.

options.label: B
options.text: The mixed air from the conducting zone and alveoli.

options.label: C
options.text: The pure alveolar air coming from the alveolar region.

options.label: D
options.text: The closing volume of the lungs.

questions.correct_answer: C. The pure alveolar air coming from the alveolar region.

questions.text: Which statement correctly describes normal inspiration?

options.label: A
options.text: Diaphragm relaxation leads to decreased intrapleural pressure, allowing air to enter the lungs.

options.label: B
options.text: Diaphragm contraction creates negative intrapleural pressure, causing air to enter the lungs.

options.label: C
options.text: Increased intra-alveolar pressure from diaphragm contraction draws air into the lungs.

options.label: D
options.text: External intercostal muscle relaxation decreases intrapleural pressure, expanding the alveoli.

questions.correct_answer: B. Diaphragm contraction creates negative intrapleural pressure, causing air to enter the lungs.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about intra-alveolar pressure changes during normal breathing is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: The maximum and minimum intra-alveolar pressure is at start of expiration and start of inspiration respectively

options.label: B
options.text: Minimum Intra-alveolar pressure is approximately -1 mm Hg during inspiration.

options.label: C
options.text: Maximum Intra-alveolar pressure is approximately +1 mm Hg during expiration.

options.label: D
options.text: At the end of both inspiration and expiration, intra-alveolar pressure is 0 mm Hg.

questions.correct_answer: A. The maximum and minimum intra-alveolar pressure is at start of expiration and start of inspiration respectively
questions.explanation:
Phase of Respiration

Intra-Alveolar Pressure (IAP)

Resting Condition

0 mm Hg

Start of Inspiration

0 mm Hg

Middle of Inspiration

-1 mm Hg

End of Inspiration

0 mm Hg

Start of Expiration

0 mm Hg

Middle of Expiration

+1 mm Hg

End of Expiration

0 mm Hg

questions.text: Match the following zones of the lungs with their corresponding pressure relationships and blood flow characteristics. Zone Pressure Relationship Blood Flow Characteristic 1 A) Pulmonary artery pressure > Pulmonary venous pressure > Alveolar pressure i) Continuous blood flow 2 B) Alveolar pressure > Pulmonary artery pressure > Pulmonary venous pressure ii) No blood flow 3 C) Pulmonary artery pressure > Alveolar pressure > Pulmonary venous pressure iii) Intermittent blood flow (only during systole)

options.label: A
options.text: 1 - A - i, 2 - B - ii, 3 - C - iii

options.label: B
options.text: 1 - B - ii, 2 - C - iii, 3 - A - i

options.label: C
options.text: 1 - C - iii, 2 - B - ii, 3 - A - i

options.label: D
options.text: 1 - B - ii, 2 - A - i, 3 - C - iii

questions.correct_answer: B. 1 - B - ii, 2 - C - iii, 3 - A - i
questions.explanation:
Zone

Pressure Relationship

Blood Flow Characteristic

1

Alveolar pressure > Pulmonary artery pressure > Pulmonary venous pressure

No blood flow, as alveolar pressure occludes the capillaries.

2

Pulmonary artery pressure > Alveolar pressure > Pulmonary venous pressure

Intermittent blood flow occurs during systole.

3

Pulmonary artery pressure > Pulmonary venous pressure > Alveolar pressure

Continuous blood flow.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

options.label: B
options.text: Elastic tissue recoil and surface tension oppose each other during expansion of alveoli

options.label: C
options.text: Hyaline membrane disease has low compliance and high surface tension

options.label: D
options.text: Low compliance of the lungs is seen in Atelectasis

questions.correct_answer: B. Elastic tissue recoil and surface tension oppose each other during expansion of alveoli
